sect1.title: Purpose
sect1.para: Many applications need to query user input or give feedback during their runtime. Often such in- or output is requested or presented by using modal dialogs that are opened over the application UI. The Common Rich Dialogs that are contained in the IvyAddOns project provide a general and customizable implementation of such often-used user-interaction dialogs.

tip.para: Please have a look at the Common Rich Dialog demo in the IvyDemos project to see a demonstration of the utility dialogs that are described in this chapter. Check out the process logic of the Common Rich Dialogs to learn more about their implementation and to adapt them to your own needs.

sect2.title: Error Dialog
sect2.para: Displays a Java Exception error to the user (Throwable instance that was e.g. caught with try/catch) . The error's stacktrace can be viewed in an own sub dialog and can be copied to the clipboard (e.g. to be pasted into a mail). The appearance of buttons can be configured.

row.entry: Displays the message of the given Throwable and optionally displays Detail and Copy buttons.
Asks user for name and password and logs him/her into the current session.
Same as login() but additionally shows a combo box that allows the user to select from a list of available application languages.

sect2.title: Message Dialog
sect2.para: Displays a message to the user. The title of the dialog can be optionally configured.

row.entry: Displays the given String to the user.
Displays the given String to the user and sets the provide title on the dialog.

sect2.title: Multi-line Input Dialog
sect2.para: Asks the user for a longer text input. The question and initial input value can be provided, as well as the buttons that should be displayed. In the most customizable start method, the buttons that will be displayed can be configured to a great extent.

row.entry: Displays the given question to the user and presents the given initial input value. For each String in the provided List, a button is created with the String as Text. When the user clicks on a button then the dialog closes and returns both the input and the String of the clicked button.

Same as askInput(String,String,List<String>):String,String but additionally allows to define one of the provided buttons as default button. This button will be invoked when the user hits enter (outside the focus of the input text area).
Same as askInput(String,String,List<String>,String):String,String but additionally allows to further customize the displayed buttons with action commands and icons.

sect2.title: Question Dialog
sect2.para: Asks the user a question that he or she can answer with a click on a button. The question the answer buttons that will be displayed can be provided.

row.entry: Displays the given question with the given icon (uri) to the user. For each String in the provided List, a button is created with the String as Text. When the user clicks on a button then the dialog closes and returns the String of the clicked button.
Same as askQuestion(String,String,List<String>):String but additionally allows to define one of the provided buttons as default button. This button will be invoked when the user hits enter.
Same as askQuestion(String,String,List<String>):String but additionally allows to provide the title of the displayed dialog.

Same as askQuestionWithTitle(String,String,String,List<String>):String but additionally allows to define one of the provided buttons as default button. This button will be invoked when the user hits enter.
Same as askQuestionWithTitle(String,String,String,List<String>,String):String but additionally allows to customize the displayed buttons with individual icon (uris) and action commands.

sect2.title: Single-line Input Dialog
sect2.para: Asks the user for a single line input. The question and initial input value can be provided, as well as the buttons that should be displayed. In the most customizable start method, the buttons that will be displayed can be configured to a great extent.

This dialog is completely identical to Multi-line Input Dialog with the only difference that a TextField instead of a TextArea is displayed for input. See Multi-line Input Dialog for a detailed description of the available start methods.
